body:
I have not updated the external document for a while.  Let me work on it this week so it matches what is actually coded.

Thank you all for reviewing this code.
The changes look good to me. Just some questions.
Change looks great to me Selva. I am not sure how we can merge when PR tests has failed? Should we rerun tests? Or maybe do something to testware (known diff etc) as part of this pull request?

Looks good to me, too.

I had some trouble convincing myself that async operations won't cause false duplicate  row errors. Here is how I convinced myself, let me know if that's wrong:

Non-unique indexes: Each IM row contains the clustering key, so there are no conflict between rows. For conflicts between the IM delete and the IM update, we now use a pre-condition to suppress conflicting deletes and inserts. So, we should be fine with async operations.

Unique indexes: They could conflict between rows. In some cases the compiler will add a blocking operator (a sort) to avoid those conflicts. Async should be ok for those. In other cases we might not have the blocking operator. For those, there is already a risk of false duplicate errors, so async is not fundamentally altering the picture. Also, the compiler uses a "robust delete", which also checks the clustering key, so that the IM operation does not delete an index row for another base table row.

Hans, I think the union between the delete and insert for index maintenance is a blocked union. Will that not be enough to prevent false uniquness violations for unique indexes (with and without async) when blocking sort is absent?

Currently, we support insert command only with unique indexes. So, async operation is not an issue. When we support upsert command, we need to ensure that async operation can work with unique indexes too. 

 With the following table definition for t12 and unique index t12i3, let's say the following rows already exist

(1,2,3,4)
(11,12,13,14)

I am not sure about the semantics of the upsert command with unique indexes. Which of the following commands should succeed?

Upsert (1,2,3,4) 
Upsert(1,2,3,5)  
Upsert (1,11,3,4) 

-- Definition of Trafodion table TRAFODION.SELVA.T12
-- Definition current  Thu Sep 10 20:41:39 2015

  (
    A                                LARGEINT NO DEFAULT NOT NULL NOT DROPPABLE
      SERIALIZED
  , B                                INT NO DEFAULT NOT NULL NOT DROPPABLE
      SERIALIZED
  , C                                INT DEFAULT NULL SERIALIZED
  , D                                INT DEFAULT NULL SERIALIZED
  , "_SALT_"                         INT UNSIGNED NO DEFAULT NOT NULL NOT
      DROPPABLE SERIALIZED
  )
  PRIMARY KEY ("_SALT_" ASC, A ASC, B ASC)

-- Definition of Trafodion unique index T12I3
-- Definition current  Thu Sep 10 20:41:39 2015

  (
    D                                INT DEFAULT NULL SERIALIZED
  , "_SALT_"                         INT UNSIGNED NO DEFAULT NOT NULL NOT
      DROPPABLE SERIALIZED
  , A                                LARGEINT NO DEFAULT NOT NULL NOT DROPPABLE
      SERIALIZED
  , B                                INT NO DEFAULT NOT NULL NOT DROPPABLE
      SERIALIZED
  )
  PRIMARY KEY
  (
    D ASC
  )

Suresh makes a good point that I hadn't understood well before. I guess I didn't assume that we wait for the async delete to be complete before we send the up queue entry, so we still ensure that the delete happens before the insert.

About Selva's question:

upsert (1,2,3,4) (set d=4) ==> Success, pre-condition skips index maintenance?
upsert(1,2,3,5) (set d=5) ==> Success, delete 4 and insert 5 into the unique index.
upsert 1,11,3,4) (insert (1,11,3,4) ==> Success if we did second upsert, failure without second upsert
upsert (1,2,3,14) ==> Failure, duplicate 14

It might be better to use showddl and real SQL statements to make sure the scenario is not ambiguous.
I am about to enable upsert for table with unique indexes. Will checkout these scenarios and report back.

Async operation doesn't wait for the individual operation in the IM to complete before we send the up queue entry. In fact, the up query entry is sent so that other operators can do their part and push their operation to hbase. The async operation is forced to wait for completion after processing either a single down queue entry or multiple down queue entries depending upon the type of operator involved(Single row operation or rowset operation). 

If the order of operations is important for unique indexes, then the async operation should be disabled. For the above use cases with the unique indexes, the async operation shouldn't be problem at all. I just went through these cases with Suresh and we think the order of operation is not needed due to pre-condition.

For the update command where-in the rows needs to be deleted before the new values can be inserted ( similar to updating a column value in a multi-column primary key), the plan is complex. The plan operates in async fashion for the old rows first and then operates in async fashion for the new rows.

Thanks to Suresh, we concluded that it should be ok to have async operation enabled for this case too.

Also, just wanted to update the PR with this info. The IM(index maintenance)  tree portion of the plan for any command alone will be non-blocking.with the exception of single row delete operation in the IM tree. Currently, this delete operation uses ExHbaseAccessUMD tcb and this operator is not conducive for async operation. So, we need to make this operation non-blocking by introducing a new TCB tree.  In addition, we can make the operation on the base table also to be non-blocking along with the IM tree if we rework the ExHbaseAccessUMD operator.

I will work on making  the single row delete operation in the IM tree as non-blocking next.
Excited about this change. I did not see anything that could be improved. Can merge after a few other look at it.
Looks good to me. Do you think that we should include only the client side hbase jar files alone in the CLASSPATH. Is it feasible to do it?

There are several opportunities to shorten the classpath: One is including only the client jar files, another is avoiding the duplication of the Hadoop jars in HBase and the Hadoop jars in Hadoop. We do call more interfaces than just what's in the client, so as far as I remember, reducing the jars included is a tedious and not very effective thing to do.
Just wanted to check: Are we ready to commit this change? Suresh, Hans, any outstanding concerns? Selva, is there anything you wish to update before commit?

Dave, I am done with the code changes unless there are more review
comments. I just need to correct my last comment about the differences
between upsert and insert.

Selva

Looks good to me too. Thank you. Shall we merge this change or would you like to wait for more pairs of eyes to look at this Roberta?

Thanks for the change Roberta. Looks good - do please go ahead and merge.

Just a note - CommonLogger does use the following (isGreaterOrEqual)- maybe this could be used in future changes rather than explicitly comparing levels - that way it will be independent of the actual enum values (difference between log4cxx and the previous logging mechanism used). 

result = ( myLevel != log4cxx::Level::getOff() && myLevel->isGreaterOrEqual(log4cxx::Level::getDebug()) )
Test failure seem to be related to generation or usage of certificate file, currently suspect some permission issues - checking.

Great, thanks!

Amanda Moran

seems like CLUSTERNAME is getting set, hence mxosrvrs look for the certificate file in $HOME/sqcert rather than $MY_SQROOT/sqcert. I think we should not set the default value in trafodion_config_default.

trafodion_config_default:export CLUSTERNAME=""

Also do please look into sqenvcom.sh for CLUSTERNAME check.
Can one of the committers verify this patch?
This a B/R script change, not covered by current regression tests. The change looks good. Thank you Prashanth. Merging.
Can one of the committers verify this patch?

Happy to report that with the fix for Trafodion 1456 all the 4 upsert test cases Selva proposed above work as Hans expects them to.

Results below. Thank you for such a good test case Selva, Hans.

> > --- SQL operation complete.
> > create unique index t12i3 on t12(d);

> > --- 2 row(s) inserted.
> > select \* from t12 ;

> > 
> > ---

```
              11           12           13           14
```

> > set parserflags 1 ;

--- SQL operation complete.

D@           _SALT_      A                     B

```

```

```
     14           1                    11           12
```

```

      5           0                     1            2
     14           1                    11           12
```


> > upsert into t12 values (1,11,3,4) ;

**\* ERROR[8102] The operation is prevented by a unique constraint.

--- 0 row(s) inserted.

> > upsert into t12 values (1,2,3,14) ;

**\* ERROR[8102] The operation is prevented by a unique constraint.

Changes look good to me. I take it the insert expression (generalization of the delete expression to insDel expression) is there for views with check option?

Issues found by Selva and Dave have been addressed. View with check option was not being processed correctly by merge, this is now disabled. Thank you very much forthe review. I will be merging this change in in the next 30 mins, unless there are objections.
Aside from the line comments/questions I made above, it all looks good.

Changes look great. Happy to have this feature. I don't see anything that can be improved immediately. Ready to merge if when everyone else is.

I have two questions more for the future.
1) Can the external Trafodion table that points to a native Hive/HBase table be created by Update stats itself? At this point it looks like we do not allow direct access to these external tables, so it seems to make the user's experience more cumbersome to have the user create these tables that are used by Update stats alone. Maybe update stats can create it if the external table does not exist?

2) I did not see an example of CREATE TABLE LIKE for a native HBase table in the regression tests and did not catch any code for it. I am sure I missed it. I was curious about what the Trafodion columns will look like for _ROW_ and _CELL_ format.

Maybe a wiki or some kind of write-up on how stats can be obtained on native tables (with sampling) will be useful. I don't have the entire process clear in my head. Thank you.

Hi Suresh,

Thanks a lot for the comments.

Currently the update stats will create the external table if it does not
exist.  The chain of logic is happening starting from the method
objExist(NABoolean createExternalTable). When ObjectUID fetched is 0 (or -1
for any error), the new code will try to create the external table and
fetch the ObjectUID again. This will be done for any native tables (HBase
or HIVE).

Thanks --Qifan

How big are these jpeg files?
Do we have legal right to use them (even as tests data)?
Could the test scripts download or generate data rather than including them in the source code?

The files need to be on platform. They don't have any copyright issues, they are used to test chunking and inserting into lobs in parts. If I make them smaller, the code won't get exercised. 
-rw-rw-r--. 1 sandhyasun sandhyasun 431839 Sep 17 06:06 anoush.jpg
-rw-rw-r--. 1 sandhyasun sandhyasun 211849 Sep 17 06:06 deep.jpg 
Looks like there are expected and test files that are larger than this too.
Does anyone have a concern with these size files being checked in ?
Can one of the committers verify this patch?
I'll go ahead and raise the size limit that the static checks checking for, so the tests can proceed.
Looks good. I will commit it...

Code changes look good. I have the same question as Steve on the pictures though: Are they in the public domain? If not, perhaps substitute some other pictures? (Could just snap a picture on your phone perhaps.)
The native table changes look good.
Yes pictures are public domain - no copyright notices.
